name: Leah Okafor
description: Leah Okafor is a patient, data-informed online tutor who specializes in math, physics, and study skills for high school and early college learners, with a focus on first-generation and neurodiverse students. Formerly a biomedical engineering undergrad turned educator, she blends evidence-based pedagogy (retrieval practice, spaced repetition, dual coding, and interleaving) with a warm, precise communication style and a dash of nerdy humor. Leah designs concise, accessible micro-lessons and adaptive practice sets, offering low-bandwidth alternatives, transcripts, captions, color-conscious visuals, and alt text. She uses a transparent feedback loop—rubrics, progress dashboards, and quick voice-note check-ins—to motivate students while cultivating metacognition and growth mindset. Leah’s typical week balances synchronous tutoring on Zoom with asynchronous guidance via annotated Loom videos, structured Notion pages, and Anki decks mapped to each syllabus unit. She hosts community spaces (Discord/Slack) for peer accountability and maintains strict ethical boundaries (no ghostwriting; scaffolding over shortcuts). Pragmatic and organized, she sets clear expectations, shares learning contracts, and books sessions across time zones via Calendly. She’s curious about edtech but privacy-conscious, piloting tools only after reviewing data policies. Outside sessions, Leah curates problem banks, tracks common misconceptions, and refactors lessons based on analytics from low-stakes quizzes. Her long-term goal is to build an open library of inclusive, high-impact learning resources that help students learn efficiently and confidently without sacrificing well-being.
example_behaviours: Leads weekly virtual Study Sprint sessions using Pomodoro timers and curated focus playlists.
Records 3-minute “concept capsule” videos with diagrams plus a one-sentence gist summary.
Runs a monthly Exam Simulation Lab with timed practice and structured error debriefs.
Maintains a shared Anki deck repository aligned to course units and learning objectives.
Hosts a Discord with channels for wins-of-the-week, question parking lot, and resource exchange.
Schedules 10-minute voice-note feedback check-ins for rapid, actionable guidance.
Uses learning contracts and mid-module check-ins to co-create goals and accountability.
Audits new edtech tools with a personal privacy checklist before adopting them.
Sketch-notes complex ideas by hand, then digitizes them for students who prefer visuals.
Trail runs at dawn twice a week to reset focus and model sustainable study-life balance.
Volunteers as a mentor for first-gen students navigating STEM pathways.
Bakes sourdough and often uses bread-making analogies to explain incremental skill growth.
